title: Gwenn ha du (Breton paramilitary group)
text:
Gwenn ha Du (<a href="Breton%20language">Breton</a> for "white and black") was a <a href="paramilitary">paramilitary</a> group founded at the end of 1930 in <a href="Paris">Paris</a> by <a href="C%C3%A9lestin%20Lain%C3%A9">Célestin Lainé</a>. It advocated <a href="Breton%20nationalism">Breton nationalism</a> through "<a href="direct%20action">direct action</a>" and published a secret manual aimed at instructing readers in terrorism. The phrase "Gwenn ha du" is the nickname for the <a href="Flag%20of%20Brittany">Breton flag</a>, which is in these colours.
History.
Statue bombing.
In July 1932, Gwenn ha Du decided to destroy a monument it found particularly offensive: a statue created by <a href="Jean%20Boucher%20%28artist%29">Jean Boucher</a> marking the union of <a href="Brittany">Brittany</a> and <a href="France">France</a> in 1532. Its unveiling some twenty years earlier triggered the first protest by <a href="breton%20nationalism">Breton Nationalists</a>. <a href="C%C3%A9lestin%20Lain%C3%A9">Célestin Lainé</a> made a <a href="bomb">bomb</a> in his bedroom, consisting of a <a href="condensed%20milk">condensed milk</a> carton filled with <a href="nitroglycerine">nitroglycerine</a>. In the early hours of August 7, he set the bomb behind the head of the King of France's statue in the facade opposite the <a href="mayor">mayor</a>'s office. At 4:00 a.m., the bomb detonated, shattering the <a href="bronze">bronze</a> statue and all <a href="glass">glass</a> within 100 metres. On August 7, the group claimed responsibility for the attack, which was intended to coincide with the 400th anniversary celebration of the union, taking place in <a href="Vannes">Vannes</a> under the guidance of French prime minister <a href="%C3%89douard%20Herriot">Édouard Herriot</a>. "<a href="L%27Humanit%C3%A9">L'Humanité</a>", the <a href="French%20Communist%20Party">French Communist Party</a> newspaper, spoke out the day after, protesting that Herriot didn't mention that all <a href="Celt">Celt</a>ic civilisation was wiped out, the refusal to acknowledge the <a href="Breton%20language">Breton language</a> and <a href="Breton%20culture">culture</a>. The authorities arrested six militants on August 11; the six remained imprisoned for fifty days.
Later attacks.
The Gwenn ha du, which presented itself as the unofficial military wing of the <a href="Parti%20National%20Breton">Parti National Breton</a>, followed up with a few months of action. On November 20, Gwenn ha du members detonated a bomb on the <a href="railway">railway</a> line between <a href="Ingrandes%2C%20Maine-et-Loire">Ingrandes</a> and <a href="Champtoc%C3%A9">Champtocé</a>, not long before Édouard Herriot's arrival there. The train stopped in front of the damaged rails. However, Herriot eventually got to <a href="Nantes">Nantes</a> in time to celebrate the act of the <a href="Union%20between%20Brittany%20and%20France">Union between Brittany and France</a>. Three more attacks followed: April 13, 1936, with <a href="arson">arson</a> in four <a href="pr%C3%A9fecture">préfecture</a>s; December 18, 1938, with the blowing up of a <a href="monument">monument</a> (the <a href="Monument%20de%20la%20F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration%20bretonne-angevine">Monument de la Fédération bretonne-angevine</a> in <a href="Pontivy">Pontivy</a>); and the attack in the préfecture of <a href="Quimper%2C%20Finist%C3%A8re">Quimper</a> on February 28, 1939.
Dissolution.
A last attack was suspected on 13 May 1941 against <a href="Carhaix">Carhaix</a> gendarmerie station after a statement was sent to members of the National Council in Vichy, threatening more attacks if the borders of the traditional province of Brittany were not recognised. After this the group ceased to function, its members becoming part of various <a href="milice">milice</a> groups working with the German occupying forces. Lainé himself led the <a href="Bezen%20Perrot">Bezen Perrot</a> militia, which included former Gwenn ha du activists. After the war, surviving members were either captured or fled France. Some were later associated with the <a href="Liberation%20Front%20of%20Brittany">Liberation Front of Brittany</a>, which was active in the 1960s.
